page.title:
What PRISMA is
What PRISMA is
page.normal_text:
J. Abeles – System 1, Inc., jabeles@syst1.com, PRISMA
J. Abeles – System 1, Inc., jabeles@syst1.com, PRISMA J .
A b e l e s
– S y s t e m
1 ,
I n c . ,
j a b e l e s @ s y s t 1 . c o m ,
P R I S M A
page.enlisting:
• Published by NIST in 2007 • Security Maturity Model with an corresponding database •At the Department level and at the program/bureau level •Promotes transparency and focuses accountability • Program Review for Information Security Management Assistance is PRISMA • Used to establish a baseline score card of security maturity and for continuous monitoring • Briefed to Congress and recommended by CSIA in 2008 • Published by NIST in 2007 • Security Maturity Model with an corresponding database
• Published by NIST in 2007
• Security Maturity Model with an corresponding database
•At the Department level and at the program/bureau level •Promotes transparency and focuses accountability
•At the Department level and at the program/bureau level
•Promotes transparency and focuses accountability
• Program Review for Information Security Management Assistance is PRISMA • Used to establish a baseline score card of security maturity and for continuous monitoring • Briefed to Congress and recommended by CSIA in 2008 • Program Review for Information Security Management Assistance is PRISMA
• Program Review for Information Security Management
Assistance is PRISMA
• Used to establish a baseline score card of security maturity and for continuous monitoring
• Used to establish a baseline score card of security • U s e d
t o
e s t a b l i s h
a
b a s e l i n e
s c o r e
c a r d
o f
s e c u r i t y
maturity and for continuous monitoring

page.title:
How PRISMA works
How PRISMA works
page.normal_text:
J. Abeles – System 1, Inc., jabeles@syst1.com, PRISMA
J. Abeles – System 1, Inc., jabeles@syst1.com, PRISMA J .
A b e l e s
– S y s t e m
1 ,
I n c . ,
j a b e l e s @ s y s t 1 . c o m ,
P R I S M A
page.enlisting:
• PRISMA Assessment is conducted in two parts • Documentation Review • Interview Review • Are the policies and procedures documented, accurate, and readily available? • Is security part of integrating programs (SDLC, PM, CPIC, EA) and mission delivery? • Are security policies and procedures improved as part of the security program life cycle? • Are security policies and procedures implemented (followed by the site personnel, integrated into normal operations)? • PRISMA Assessment is conducted in two parts
• PRISMA Assessment is conducted in two parts
• Documentation Review
• Documentation Review
• Interview Review
• Interview Review
• Are the policies and procedures documented, accurate, and readily available? • Is security part of integrating programs (SDLC, PM, CPIC, EA) and mission delivery? • Are security policies and procedures improved as part of the security program life cycle? • Are security policies and procedures implemented (followed by the site personnel, integrated into normal operations)? • Are the policies and procedures documented, accurate, and readily available? • Is security part of integrating programs (SDLC, PM, CPIC, EA) and mission delivery?
• Are the policies and procedures documented, accurate, and
readily available?
• Is security part of integrating programs (SDLC, PM, CPIC,
EA) and mission delivery?
• Are security policies and procedures improved as part of the security program life cycle? • Are security policies and procedures implemented (followed by the site personnel, integrated into normal operations)?
• Are security policies and procedures
improved as part of the security program
life cycle?
• Are security policies and procedures implemented (followed
by the site personnel, integrated into normal operations)?
PRISMA 2 parts common sense 1 part intuition 1 part knowledge 1 part experience
PRISMA
2 parts common sense
1 part intuition
1 part knowledge
1 part experience

P R I S M A
page.enlisting:
• This can be done for a Department and at a Program or Site level • Score can be aggregated to Department overall scorecard • Program Status – Maturity Scorecards in 9 topic areas, 30 subtopic areas • Evaluation of each topic area – Observations – Issues – Recommendations • Recommended Action Plan – Issues and recommendations – Timeframe to implement – Resource Impact • Database – Baseline that can be periodically updated to track security improvement • This can be done for a Department and at a Program or Site level • Score can be aggregated to Department overall scorecard
• This can be done for a Department and at a Program or Site level
• Score can be aggregated to Department overall scorecard

page.title:
Observations from Federal
Observations from Federal
page.enlisting:
• Information security does not receive the needed attention by leadership, and it is one of many functions that compete for scarce resources only after meeting operational needs •Executive management is out of touch with the maturity of their security program • Executive management does not see cyber security as a major threat to mission accomplishment • The organization has not developed a risk-based approach to information security based upon a clear understanding of threats to information and information systems • Information security does not receive the needed attention by leadership, and it is one of many functions that compete for scarce resources only after meeting operational needs
• Information security does not receive the needed
attention by leadership, and it is one of many functions
that compete for scarce resources only after meeting
operational needs
•Executive management is out of touch with the maturity of their security program • Executive management does not see cyber security as a major threat to mission accomplishment
•Executive management is out of touch with the maturity of their
security program
• Executive management does not see cyber security as a
major threat to mission accomplishment
• The organization has not developed a risk-based approach to information security based upon a clear understanding of threats to information and information systems
• The organization has not developed a risk-based
approach to information security based upon a clear
understanding of threats to information and information
systems
